attributes.title: Resting state functional connectivity of emotion regulation regions in aging
attributes.description: Amygdala is a region critical for emotions (Davis & Whalen, 2001). Regulation of one’s emotion is thought to result from top-down influences of cognitive control regions (prefrontal cortex and anterior cingulate cortex) on the amygdala (Ochsner & Gross, 2005). Previous brain imaging studies suggest that when individuals are reappraising their emotions compared to maintaining them, the neural connectivity of those regions become stronger (Banks, Eddy, Angstadt, Nathan, & Phan, 2007). Also, while many domains of executive control show age-related decline (for a review, see Braver & West, 2011), emotion regulation ability improves as individuals get older, such that older adults can regulate negative emotions better when facing negative stimuli due to greater prefrontal cortex activity (Nashiro, Sakaki, & Mather, 2012).    	The question for the current study is to determine to what degree individual differences in emotion regulation can be predicted from the baseline interactions of cognitive control regions with amygdala, as measured through resting state functional connectivity (RSFC). RSFC has been shown to be relatively stable within subjects across time and predict several individual characteristics, including depression, neuroticism and extraversion, and impulsivity (Greicius et al., 2007; Hsu, Rosenberg, Scheinost, Constable, & Chun, 2018; Li, et al., 2013). Across-network interactions can also predict the interactions between distinct processes, such as interactions between memory and reward processing regions predicting the degree to which a person’s memory is affected by reward (Frank, Preston, & Zeithamova, 2019). Here, we propose to use the existing Cam-CAN dataset (Shafto et al., 2014; Taylor et al., 2017) to determine to what degree emotional regulation ability can be predicted from the pattern of resting state connectivity between the emotion and cognitive control regions. As a second goal, as Cam-CAN contains data across lifespan, we are interested in whether there are age-related differences in emotion regulation and whether the relationship between the resting state functional connectivity and the ability to regulate emotions changes as a function of age.

q1.value: Resting state functional connectivity of emotion regulation regions in aging

q4.value:
1. Older subjects will show better emotion regulation abilities. 

2. Stronger functional connectivity between amygdala and cognitive control regions at resting state will be associated with better emotion regulation performance.

3. RSFC between amygdala and cognitive control regions will vary as a function of age. 

4. Age and amygdala connectivity will track distinct positions of variance in the emotional regulation success.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
- Experiment procedures - 
	We obtained the data from the Cambridge Centre for Ageing and Neuroscience (Cam-CAN) study (Shafto et al., 2014; Taylor et al., 2017). The Cam-CAN is a large-scale imaging project at the University of Cambridge to examine neural mechanisms of cognitive aging. The Cam-CAN study consisted of three stages, but the data used in the proposed study is from the second stage. A total of 656 subjects were recruited for the second stage of the Cam-CAN, consisting of 56 subjects from the youngest decade (18-27) (due to recruitment problems) and 100 subjects from each decile age 28-87.  Subjects were asked to complete various cognitive experiments in three separate sessions. The proposed study will utilize resting state MRI data collected in session 1 and behavioral data from an emotional reactivity and regulation task collected in session 3. Only half of the total Cam-CAN subjects completed the emotional reactivity and regulation task (the other half completed a different task) and thus will be analyzed in the present study. Also, being left-handed and ambidextrous (assessed through the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory) was an exclusion criterion for the proposed study (See Shafto et al., 2014 for more details). We will only use the data of right-handed subjects because previous studies observe brain asymmetries among individuals with different handedness (e.g., Willems, Hagoort, & Casasanto, 2010), and most neuroimaging studies on cognition have been conducted with right-handed subjects. 

1. Emotional reactivity and regulation task. This task was part of the third session in which half of the Cam-CAN subjects completed it. Shafto et al. (2014) reported detailed experimental procedures. Briefly, subjects were asked to watch 30 seconds movie clips that were classified as neutral, positive, and negative. There were four conditions that every subject underwent: 1) watch neutral, 2) watch positive, 3) watch negative, 4) reappraise negative. For each trial before a movie clip was shown, subjects were given a prompt to indicate the valence of the movie clip they were about to watch (i.e., neutral, positive, or negative) and how they should watch it (i.e., watch or reappraise). Then, a movie clip was shown. After each clip, subjects were asked to provide a rating on two 0-100 scales indicating how much positive or negative emotion they felt, from “0 = Not Negative/Positive” to “100 = Extremely Negative/Positive”. Subjects were also asked to rate how well they adhered to the task instruction (i.e., watch or reappraise). There were eight blocks, and each block consisted of four runs (one run from each condition).

2. MRI scans. Both structural and functional MRI scans were collected during the first session (Detailed procedures reported in Taylor et al., 2017). In the proposed study, we will be using T1 structural images and resting state functional images. 



- MRI data preprocessing -
	Functional MRI images will be skull-stripped using BET (Brain Extraction Tool), which is part of FSL. Within-run motion correction will be computed using MCFLIRT in FSL using the middle volume as an initial template image. We will use recommended procedures to control for motion and physiological noise-related signal fluctuations that otherwise affect RSFC values (Power, Barnes, Snyder, Schlaggar, & Petersen 2012). First, we will extract the time series for cerebrospinal fluid, white matter, and whole-brain signal and calculate framewise displacement (FD) and global signal change (DVARS) for the rest scan. These values will be used to exclude volumes with too much motion and noise: individual volumes will be removed if either FD exceeded 0.5 mm or DVARS exceeded 0.5%, as well as one volume before and two volumes after each flagged volume. The first two volumes and the last volume of the rest run will also be excluded. 
	
- Regions of Interest -
	Regions of interest (ROIs) will be defined by parcellating and segmenting high resolution anatomical images using Freesurfer in their native space. Each brain region will be collapsed across hemispheres. Our ROIs include amygdala, ventral medial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC), middle frontal gyrus (MFG), inferior frontal gyrus (IFG), and anterior cingulate cortex (ACC). Amygdala is a critical region for emotions (Davis & Whalen, 2001), and our cognitive control ROIs (VMPFC, MFG, IFG, ACC) have been implicated in their roles on emotion regulation regarding the amygdala (Banks et al., 2007; Etkin, Büchel, & Gross, 2015; Kim et al, 2011). We will also include hippocampus to serve as a control region for amygdala because it is a subcortical region adjacent to amygdala, but its connectivity to prefrontal control regions would not be expected to relate to emotion regulation.

- Measuring connectivity -
	Connectivity will be measured as the partial correlation between each of our seed regions (amygdala and hippocampus) and each cortical ROI (VMPFC, MFG, IFG, ACC) while controlling for motion and physiological noise. We will include the standard six realignment motion parameters, the above described physiological noise parameters (cerebrospinal fluid, white matter, whole brain signal), and all their derivatives as nuisance regressors. The resulting correlation coefficients will be Fisher z-transformed for subsequent analysis.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Data has been downloaded from the Cam-CAN database. The procedures used to collect all the data are reported in Shafto et al. (2014) and Taylor et al. (2017). We have submitted an abstract of our proposed study to the Cam-CAN and been granted the access to the data.

q14.value: We obtained imaging data of 654 subjects from the Cam-CAN database, of which 314 subjects were in the third session with the emotional reactivity and regulation task (See “Study design” for more details). After excluding people who are not right-handed based on the handedness test that was administered, 262 subjects met the criteria for our proposed study.

question.value:
1. Resting state functional connectivity: We will measure resting state functional connectivity (RSFC) between the amygdala and each cognitive control ROIs (VMPFC, MFG, IFG, ACC). As a control, we will also measure connectivity between hippocampus and each of the cognitive control regions. Thus, four connectivity values per subject will be used for the main analyses, and four connectivity values per subject will be used for the control analyses. 

2. Emotional reactivity and regulation ratings: The Cam-CAN database contains three measures (mean positive emotion rating, mean negative emotion rating, mean watch vs. reappraise task compliance rating) for each of four conditions (watch neutral, watch positive, watch negative, reappraise negative). Out of these 12 total behavioral variables, we will generate three constructs of interest.

1. Emotion reactivity. Emotion reactivity will assess to what degree subjects’ ratings were sensitive to the emotional content of the video stimuli and will be measured using two scores: (1) For each subject, mean positive ratings will be subtracted between the watch-positive and watch-negative conditions to indicate decrease in positivity ratings related to watching a negative (as opposed to positive) clip. (2) For each subject, mean negative ratings will be subtracted between the watch-positive and watch-negative conditions to measure increase in negativity ratings related to negative (as opposed to positive) clips. If positive and negative ratings are strongly correlated within each condition, they will be collapsed into a single “emotional reactivity” rating for each subject by subtracting the negative ratings from the positive ratings.  

2. Subjective feeling of emotion regulation. To capture to what degree subjects felt they were following the reappraise instructions, we will subtract a subject’s mean watch vs. reappraise ratings between the condition in which they were shown negative clips and instructed to reappraise (reappraise-negative) and the condition in which they were not instructed to reappraise (watch-negative).

3. Emotion regulation success. Emotion regulation success is the main behavioral effect of interest for which we have specific hypotheses. Emotion regulation scores will capture to what degree emotional response to negative stimuli changes as a function of reappraise instruction (watch vs. reappraise). Similar to emotion reactivity, emotion regulation will be initially measured using two scores: (1) Subtracting a subject’s mean positive rating for the reappraise-negative condition from the one for the watch-negative condition. (2) Subtracting a subject’s mean negative rating for the reappraise-negative condition from the one for the watch-negative condition. If these scores are strongly correlated, they will be collapsed into a single composite “emotional regulation” rating for each subject by subtracting the differences in negative ratings from the differences in positive ratings.

- Behavioral analyses – 
	To test for the degree of emotional reactivity, subjective feeling of emotion regulation, and emotion regulation success, we will compute the mean scores on each of these measures of interests. Because all of the measures are the difference scores, we will test them against the null hypothesis that the difference scores are zero on average (equivalence to paired t-tests comparing the two components of each score, e.g., positive ratings to positive clips vs. positive ratings to negative clips). 

	To test whether age relates to emotional reactivity and regulation, we will first conduct zero-order correlations between each emotion-related index and age (as a continuous variable). Further, we will test the same hypothesis by treating age as a categorical variable. Subjects will be divided into 3 age groups (young=18-30, middle=30-59, old=60+) and then perform a 2 (conditions) x 3 (age: young, middle, old) ANOVAs. This would allow us to capture non-linear age-related changes. Finally, even when no single measure may significantly relate to age, there may be an effect when all emotion reactivity and regulation measures are combined. We will thus perform a multiple regression with age as an outcome and all emotion-related constructs of interest as predictors. Overall model fit as well as the coefficients for each predictive construct will be tested.

- Connectivity analyses – 
	Relationship between amygdala connectivity and emotion regulation: We hypothesize that stronger RSFC between the amygdala and cognitive control regions will be associated with better emotion regulation performance. In order to examine this hypothesis, we will first conduct multiple regressions with the four amygdala-cortex connectivity measures as predictors and the emotion regulation success index as an outcome. We will assess the overall fit of the model as well as coefficients for each connectivity measure. As a second approach, support vector regressions (SVR) will be used to predict emotion regulation success from the pattern of our four connectivity measures. We will randomly divide our subjects into five groups regardless of their age and perform 5-fold cross validation to test the SVR model. 

	Relationship between connectivity and age: To quantify how connectivity values relate to age, we will conduct two analyses: First, age will be correlated with each amygdala-cortex connection value, and secondly, multiple regressions will be conducted with the four connections as predictors and age as outcome. If we find that age and connectivity are related, we will also run a regression with the four connectivity values and age predicting emotion regulation success to assess if age and connectivity explain distinct variance in emotion regulation.

	Testing whether the association between amygdala connectivity and emotion regulation is age-dependent: We will conduct a multiple regression with one connectivity measure, age, and an interaction between the connectivity measure and age to predict emotion regulation success. Separate regressions will be conducted for each connectivity measure to examine if any of the connectivity x age interactions track individual differences in emotion regulation. 
	
	Lastly, we will conduct all of the aforementioned connectivity analyses using hippocampus – cognitive control regions RSFC as our control analyses.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining if inference tests are significant.

q22.value: Subjects who have excessive motion during the resting scan will be excluded from the analyses.

- Measuring connectivity -
	Connectivity will be measured as the partial correlation between each of our seed regions (amygdala and hippocampus) and each cortical ROI (VMPFC, MFG, IFG, ACC) while controlling for motion and physiological noise. We will include the standard six realignment motion parameters, the above described physiological noise parameters (cerebrospinal fluid, white matter, whole brain signal), and all their derivatives as nuisance regressors. The resulting correlation coefficients will be Fisher z-transformed for subsequent analysis.
registration_responses.q12.question: Data has been downloaded from the Cam-CAN database. The procedures used to collect all the data are reported in Shafto et al. (2014) and Taylor et al. (2017). We have submitted an abstract of our proposed study to the Cam-CAN and been granted the access to the data.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1. Resting state functional connectivity: We will measure resting state functional connectivity (RSFC) between the amygdala and each cognitive control ROIs (VMPFC, MFG, IFG, ACC). As a control, we will also measure connectivity between hippocampus and each of the cognitive control regions. Thus, four connectivity values per subject will be used for the main analyses, and four connectivity values per subject will be used for the control analyses. 

2. Emotional reactivity and regulation ratings: The Cam-CAN database contains three measures (mean positive emotion rating, mean negative emotion rating, mean watch vs. reappraise task compliance rating) for each of four conditions (watch neutral, watch positive, watch negative, reappraise negative). Out of these 12 total behavioral variables, we will generate three constructs of interest.
registration_responses.q18.question:
1. Emotion reactivity. Emotion reactivity will assess to what degree subjects’ ratings were sensitive to the emotional content of the video stimuli and will be measured using two scores: (1) For each subject, mean positive ratings will be subtracted between the watch-positive and watch-negative conditions to indicate decrease in positivity ratings related to watching a negative (as opposed to positive) clip. (2) For each subject, mean negative ratings will be subtracted between the watch-positive and watch-negative conditions to measure increase in negativity ratings related to negative (as opposed to positive) clips. If positive and negative ratings are strongly correlated within each condition, they will be collapsed into a single “emotional reactivity” rating for each subject by subtracting the negative ratings from the positive ratings.  

2. Subjective feeling of emotion regulation. To capture to what degree subjects felt they were following the reappraise instructions, we will subtract a subject’s mean watch vs. reappraise ratings between the condition in which they were shown negative clips and instructed to reappraise (reappraise-negative) and the condition in which they were not instructed to reappraise (watch-negative).

3. Emotion regulation success. Emotion regulation success is the main behavioral effect of interest for which we have specific hypotheses. Emotion regulation scores will capture to what degree emotional response to negative stimuli changes as a function of reappraise instruction (watch vs. reappraise). Similar to emotion reactivity, emotion regulation will be initially measured using two scores: (1) Subtracting a subject’s mean positive rating for the reappraise-negative condition from the one for the watch-negative condition. (2) Subtracting a subject’s mean negative rating for the reappraise-negative condition from the one for the watch-negative condition. If these scores are strongly correlated, they will be collapsed into a single composite “emotional regulation” rating for each subject by subtracting the differences in negative ratings from the differences in positive ratings.
registration_responses.q19.question:
- Behavioral analyses – 
	To test for the degree of emotional reactivity, subjective feeling of emotion regulation, and emotion regulation success, we will compute the mean scores on each of these measures of interests. Because all of the measures are the difference scores, we will test them against the null hypothesis that the difference scores are zero on average (equivalence to paired t-tests comparing the two components of each score, e.g., positive ratings to positive clips vs. positive ratings to negative clips). 

	To test whether age relates to emotional reactivity and regulation, we will first conduct zero-order correlations between each emotion-related index and age (as a continuous variable). Further, we will test the same hypothesis by treating age as a categorical variable. Subjects will be divided into 3 age groups (young=18-30, middle=30-59, old=60+) and then perform a 2 (conditions) x 3 (age: young, middle, old) ANOVAs. This would allow us to capture non-linear age-related changes. Finally, even when no single measure may significantly relate to age, there may be an effect when all emotion reactivity and regulation measures are combined. We will thus perform a multiple regression with age as an outcome and all emotion-related constructs of interest as predictors. Overall model fit as well as the coefficients for each predictive construct will be tested.

- Connectivity analyses – 
	Relationship between amygdala connectivity and emotion regulation: We hypothesize that stronger RSFC between the amygdala and cognitive control regions will be associated with better emotion regulation performance. In order to examine this hypothesis, we will first conduct multiple regressions with the four amygdala-cortex connectivity measures as predictors and the emotion regulation success index as an outcome. We will assess the overall fit of the model as well as coefficients for each connectivity measure. As a second approach, support vector regressions (SVR) will be used to predict emotion regulation success from the pattern of our four connectivity measures. We will randomly divide our subjects into five groups regardless of their age and perform 5-fold cross validation to test the SVR model. 

	Relationship between connectivity and age: To quantify how connectivity values relate to age, we will conduct two analyses: First, age will be correlated with each amygdala-cortex connection value, and secondly, multiple regressions will be conducted with the four connections as predictors and age as outcome. If we find that age and connectivity are related, we will also run a regression with the four connectivity values and age predicting emotion regulation success to assess if age and connectivity explain distinct variance in emotion regulation.

	Testing whether the association between amygdala connectivity and emotion regulation is age-dependent: We will conduct a multiple regression with one connectivity measure, age, and an interaction between the connectivity measure and age to predict emotion regulation success. Separate regressions will be conducted for each connectivity measure to examine if any of the connectivity x age interactions track individual differences in emotion regulation. 
	
	Lastly, we will conduct all of the aforementioned connectivity analyses using hippocampus – cognitive control regions RSFC as our control analyses.

attributes.title: Effectiveness of Cognitive Interventions on Cognitive Outcomes of Adult ICU Survivors: A Scoping Review
attributes.description: Scoping Review on Adult ICU survivors

q1.value: Effectiveness of Cognitive Interventions on Cognitive Outcomes of Adult ICU Survivors: A Scoping Review

q2.value: Olga Muradov, Elisavet Papathanasoglou, Olga Petrovskaya

q3.value:
Traditionally, there had been an enormous weight placed on critical care practitioners to focus on survivorship of patients to demonstrate success of treatment, rather than on the improvement of patients’ long-term outcomes. PICS encompasses multiple patient and  responses impacting survivors’ long-term health outcomes, including physical function, psychiatric impairments, and cognitive impairments.
	Cognitive interventions to rehabilitate the devastating consequences of cognitive impairments and their potential impact on improving long-term outcomes of survivors have recently been sought but no effective treatment guidelines have been established. There is a necessity for rapid translation of novel interdisciplinary care models, designed for ICU survivors, who are burdened by cognitive impairments, into clinical practice in the near future. This is a gap that the proposed scoping review aims to address. 

The purpose of this scoping review is to provide an overview and critically synthesize existing evidence on the relative effectiveness of various cognitive interventions in improving ICU survivors’ cognitive outcomes. Since no current models of care and recommended guidelines for cognitive rehabilitation strategies for PICS survivors exist to date, in part due to the complexity of definition of cognitive impairment and variability in cognitive intervention strategies, it is my aim to review available clinical and health service interventions and if and to what degree they improve cognitive outcomes for ICU survivors. Additionally, by conducting a thorough review of existing scientific literature, my aim is to extract important questions for future research.

q4.value: My research question is: Are cognitive interventions effective in improving ICU survivors’ cognitive outcomes? Evidence on all outcomes reported in primary studies will be critically synthesized.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The review process will be directed by a protocol based on the PRISMA-ScR (PRISMA extension for Scoping Reviews) developed according to published guidelines by the EQUATOR (Enhancing the QUAlity and Transparency Of Health Research) Network for the development of reporting guidelines (Tricco et al., 2018, p. 467). Given that the nature of research evidence is recently emerging, no chronological limits or other limits will be applied to literature searches. Databases will include: CINHAL, MEDLINE, EMBASE, PubMed, Scopus, Google Scholar and Cochrane Library. Reference lists of the identified studies will be screened for relevance, methodology, quality appraisal and merit.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: This is a scoping review and no primary data was collected.

question.value:
Scoping review methodology allows for inclusion of a range of sources not limited to primary studies, eg, published protocols. To meet our primary goal (identify cognitive interventions and measurable outcomes) and secondary goals (synthesize evidence on effectiveness of interventions), this review included published peer-reviewed primary papers reporting on: 1) experimental and quasi-experimental studies investigating the effectiveness of any type of cognitive intervention, as stand alone or in combination with other interventions, on adult ICU survivors’ cognitive outcomes after ICU discharge; and 2) protocols of interventional studies. 
The inclusion criteria comprised: peer-reviewed articles published in English, which a) involve adult ICU patients (18 years and older) who were discharged from ICU, irrespective of primary diagnosis and ICU type; and b) propose interventions or report the results of interventions specific to the cognitive domain after ICU discharge. No further limits were applied related to timing of initiation of treatment, location of intervention, type of comparison used, or outcomes measured.  
The exclusion criteria comprised: a) studies addressing populations under 18 years of age; b) studies involving interventions without a specific cognitive dimension e.g. only physical or psychological; c) studies reporting on interventions performed while patients were still hospitalized in the ICU; and d) secondary analyses, reviews, brief items, dissertations, conference papers.

q13.value: 497 people were included among the 5 studies included in this scoping review.

question.value: N/A: A scoping review
Global cognitive function and Executive function parameters were described after delivery of various cognitive interventions.
N/A
N/A

q25.value: This scoping review was completed in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Nursing at the University of Alberta.

attributes.title: Investigating How Unhealthy Snacking Habits Affects Self-Licensing With an Online Daily Diary Study

q1.value: Investigating How Unhealthy Snacking Habits Affects Self-Licensing With an Online Daily Diary Study

q3.value: Self-licensing is the act of making justifications for a discrepant behavior before enacting the behavior itself (De Witt Huberts et. al., 2014a). This way what would be conceived as a possible failure of the long-term goal becomes acceptable for the individual. Based on their previous research, Prinsen and her colleagues (2018) proposed that not all self-licensing acts are detrimental and self-licensing has two sides of it, namely functional and dysfunctional self-licensing. In this 7-day online daily diary study, the aim is to investigate how unhealthy snacking habit interacts with functional and dysfunctional self-licensing in explaining snack consumption.

q4.value:
1) Higher dysfunctional self-licensing score should predict higher unhealthy snack consumption in a week, after controlling for the effect of self-control.
1a) High snacking habit should moderate the effect of high dysfunctional self-licensing on the mean unhealthy snack consumption.
1b) High impulsivity score should moderate the effect of high dysfunctional self-licensing on the mean unhealthy snack consumption.
1c) High emotional appetite score should moderate the effect of high dysfunctional self-licensing on the mean unhealthy snack consumption.

2)	High functional self-licensing score should predict lower unhealthy snack intake consumed in a week, after controlling for the effect of self-control.
2a)	Low snacking habit should moderate the effect of high functional self-licensing on mean unhealthy snack consumption.
2b)  High weight-related self-efficacy score should moderate the effect of high functional self-licensing on mean unhealthy snack consumption.
2c)  High cognitive flexibility score should moderate the effect of high functional self-licensing on mean unhealthy snack consumption.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study design is correlational in nature. Specifically, it is a daily diary study in which participants are asked to send each snack (except meals) and drink (except water) they have consumed in that day for seven days.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data has been collected over Qualtrics between October 21, 2019 and December 5, 2019. However, the data was not analyzed because it took strenuous effort to code 3353 snacks and drinks into their respective caloric values, among other codings. Beside the codings, only those participants who did not adhere to the participation rules were discarded from the data.

question.value:
The data was collected from the psychology students of Kadir Has University in exchange of course credits. Participants first filled an application form (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1_uEs0OotsyGLAhsmukog1e2C5Lerkn_HU7wgWhjjNlE/edit) where they give the information of name, e-mail adress, phone number and which course they would like to take credit from. Afterwards, they were contacted in groups of 20 on sundays and wednesdays (whenever there are 20 people) to fill the main measures of the study on Qualtrics. Moreover, they were told that the day after they will be starting to send each snack and drink they consume for 7 days. 

Snack diary was also collected on Qualtrics which the link of it was sent to the participants at 11.59 PM each night. Participants entered the information of amount, type and time of each snack they consumed that day.

There were no strict eligibility criteria for participation. Contrary to most of the eating behavior studies which collect data from women, we wanted to collect data from men as well. The reason for that was to capture whether self-licensing effects are also applicable to men or not. 

In order to receive credit for participating to the study, participants had to fill the main measures and enter at least 6 days of the snack diary. Those who did not were excluded from the data.

q13.value: In total, 153 participants filled the main measures and there were 1031 entry of snack diaries. After excluding misentries and those participants who did not adhere to the participation rules, 131 participants remained in the final data (their snack diaries were discarded as well).

q14.value: The study draws heavily from Prinsen, Dohle, Evers, de Ridder and Hofmann (2018) who collected data from 67 females in total. We wanted to exceed this sample size, considering possible exclusions from the data and aimed to collect data from 150 participants.

question.value:
Demographics: Age, gender, height, weight, diet frequency, diet status (Y/N)

Main measures: 
1) Diet Descriptives: These descriptive items were retrieved directly from Prinsen et. al. (2018). Sample items include "I am motivated to lose weight", "I try to eat more healthily", which are assessed on a 7-point scale (1 = not at all, 7 =very much).

2) Restraint Eating Scale (Herman, Polivy, Pliner, Threlkeld, & Munic, 1978): This 10-item scale was used to assess participants' restraint eating practices, with a minor change in scaling of one of the item. In item 1 ("How often are you dieting?") the original scales range from never (0) to always (4), instead we changed the scales to "I never diet", "2-3 times a month", "once a month", "I start a new diet after 1-2 weeks quiting the one before", "I always diet". We thought that the original scaling misses crucial information of the participants' dieting practices. Beside this change, all the other items were used as was in van Strien et. al. (2007).

3) Functional and Dysfunctional Self-licensing Scale: This scale was developed and validated by Prinsen et. al. (2018) which involves 10-item for functional and 10-item for dysfunctional self-licensing on a 7-point scale (1 = does not apply to me at all, 7 = totally applies to me).

4) Brief Self-control Scale: The Turkish version (Nebioglu et. al., 2012) of the 13-item Brief Self-control Scale (Tangney, Baumeister, Boone, 2008) was used to assess participants' self-control levels. The scale options ranged from 1 (not at all) and 5 (Very much). 

5) Unhealthy Snack Habits Scale: Participants' habit strength of unhealthy snacking was measured with the scale developed by Verplanken and Orbell (2003). The scale wording was changed so that it reflected unhealthy snacking habit and assessed on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all agree, 5 = completely agree).

6) Weight-related Self-efficacy Scale: Wilson et. al. (2016) developed brief self-efficacy scales to be used in the weight-loss trials. These scales tap into participants' confidence with eating healthful foods, being physically active and losing weight. In this study, we measured only the 4-item losing weight scale which ranged from 0 (no confidence) to 100 (full confidence). 

7) Cognitive Flexibility Scale: The Turkish version (Altunkol, 2017) of the Cognitive Flexibility Scale (Martin and Rubin, 1995) was assessed. The scale consists of 12 items that range from 1 (Strongly disagree) to 6 (Strongly agree). 

8) Barratt's Impulsivity Scale: The Turkish version (Tamam et. al., 2012) of the Barratt's Impulsivity Scale was used to assess the impulsivity levels of the participants. The scale has 15 items that range from 1 (Rarely/Never) to 4 (Always). 

9) Emotional Appetite Scale:  The Turkish version (Demirel et. al., 2014) of the Emotional Appetite Scale was used. The scale measures changes in the amount of eating under different emotions. We did not include all of the emotions in the original scale and assessed only those emotions that we were shown to be predictor of eating in the self-licensing literature. These emotions include sadness, boredom, angry, anxious, happy, tired, pessimist, cheerful and alone. The scale ranged from 1 (eating less than normal), 5 (eating as usual) and 9 (eating more than usual). 

10) Each night for 7 days, participants will answer perceived stress and perceived sleep efficiency for the day they submit their diaries on a 10-point scale.

Outcome measures:
1) The amount of the eaten snack: Participants reported the amount of the each snack they submitted, whether as a package, handful, pieces or glasses. 

2) Type of snack: Participants reported each snack and drink they consumed that day from waking up to before going bed. They were limited to send 10 snacks and drinks per day. 

3) Time eaten the snack: We collected the data of the time eaten each snack by asking participants to record the time, along with the amount and type of snack.

1) Participants' BMI will be calculated by their height and weight information.

2) Age, gender, diet frequency and descriptives, dieting or not will not be combined but will be used only for descriptive purposes.

3) Beside the above items, each of the main measure variables' mean will be calculated, after transforming the reversed items. Three exceptions are (1) Functional and Dysfunctional Self-licensing items will be combined differently to create two means, one for each, (2) the mean of the Emotional Appetite Scale items will be taken for positive and negative emotions differently and (3) instead of the mean, the sum of scores will be used to create cognitive flexibility score of the participants.

The caloric value of the snacks reported will be assessed by multiplying the amount of the snack eaten with the caloric value of the snack. The caloric values will be obtained from different sources to be sure of the reliability of the snacks' caloric values. For the packaged snacks, the caloric information at the back of the packages will be used. For those snacks and drinks that are not packaged, the caloric information will be taken from https://www.diyetkolik.com/kac-kalori/, https://www.diyetasistan.com/besinler-kac-kalori.html, https://www.kackalori.com.tr/KaloriCetveli/ to be sure of the caloric values. 

After calculating each of the snacks and drinks' caloric value, they will be transformed into four different indexes. These four variables will be healthy snack mean, healthy drink mean, unhealthy snack mean and unhealthy drink mean. The mean of any of the above variable for a participant will be calculated by dividing the sum of caloric intake by 7. Beside from fruits, vegetables and yogurt, all the rest of the snacks will be coded as unhealthy snacks. In a similar vein, tea, sugar-free coffee, milk, mineral water will be coded as healthy drink and the rest (coke, alcoholic beverages etc.) will be coded as unhealthy drink.

For the hypotheses 1 and 2, hierarchical linear regression analysis will be used to analyze our proposed hypotheses. In both analyses, self-control, BMI will be added to the first step, and dysfunctional self-licensing (hypothesis 1) and functional self-licensing (hypothesis 2) to the second step.

For the remaining hypotheses (1a, 1b, 1c, 2a, 2b, 2c) moderation analysis will be conducted, according to the proposed predictions.

q21.value: The standard p-value (< .05) will be taken to determine significant relationships. Moreover, all the conducted analyses will be two tailed tests.

q22.value: Because the data is collected on Qualtrics, double entries for a single day  occurs. Those double entries with higher missing values will be discarded directly. Moreover, those participants who did not fill main measures or send less than 6 daily diaries will be excluded as well.

q23.value: If a participant does not fill any one of the main measures, s/he will be excluded from the analysis.

q24.value:
Previous research generally used mean unhealthy snacking as an outcome variable. However, in this study we collected the data of not only unhealthy snacks but also unhealthy drinks, healthy food and healthy drinks as well. The main measures' relationship with these to some extent less-investigated outcome variables will be examined.

Moreover, hierarchical linear modeling (HLM) will be conducted to investigate the relationship between daily consumption, stress and sleep.

4) Brief Self-control Scale: The Turkish version (Nebioglu et. al., 2012) of the 13-item Brief Self-control Scale (Tangney, Baumeister, Boone, 2008) was used to assess participants' self-control levels. The scale options ranged from 1 (not at all) and 5 (Very much). 

5) Unhealthy Snack Habits Scale: Participants' habit strength of unhealthy snacking was measured with the scale developed by Verplanken and Orbell (2003). The scale wording was changed so that it reflected unhealthy snacking habit and assessed on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all agree, 5 = completely agree).

6) Weight-related Self-efficacy Scale: Wilson et. al. (2016) developed brief self-efficacy scales to be used in the weight-loss trials. These scales tap into participants' confidence with eating healthful foods, being physically active and losing weight. In this study, we measured only the 4-item losing weight scale which ranged from 0 (no confidence) to 100 (full confidence). 

7) Cognitive Flexibility Scale: The Turkish version (Altunkol, 2017) of the Cognitive Flexibility Scale (Martin and Rubin, 1995) was assessed. The scale consists of 12 items that range from 1 (Strongly disagree) to 6 (Strongly agree). 

8) Barratt's Impulsivity Scale: The Turkish version (Tamam et. al., 2012) of the Barratt's Impulsivity Scale was used to assess the impulsivity levels of the participants. The scale has 15 items that range from 1 (Rarely/Never) to 4 (Always). 

9) Emotional Appetite Scale:  The Turkish version (Demirel et. al., 2014) of the Emotional Appetite Scale was used. The scale measures changes in the amount of eating under different emotions. We did not include all of the emotions in the original scale and assessed only those emotions that we were shown to be predictor of eating in the self-licensing literature. These emotions include sadness, boredom, angry, anxious, happy, tired, pessimist, cheerful and alone. The scale ranged from 1 (eating less than normal), 5 (eating as usual) and 9 (eating more than usual). 

10) Each night for 7 days, participants will answer perceived stress and perceived sleep efficiency for the day they submit their diaries on a 10-point scale.

Outcome measures:
1) The amount of the eaten snack: Participants reported the amount of the each snack they submitted, whether as a package, handful, pieces or glasses. 

2) Type of snack: Participants reported each snack and drink they consumed that day from waking up to before going bed. They were limited to send 10 snacks and drinks per day. 

3) Time eaten the snack: We collected the data of the time eaten each snack by asking participants to record the time, along with the amount and type of snack.
registration_responses.q18.question:
1) Participants' BMI will be calculated by their height and weight information.

2) Age, gender, diet frequency and descriptives, dieting or not will not be combined but will be used only for descriptive purposes.

3) Beside the above items, each of the main measure variables' mean will be calculated, after transforming the reversed items. Three exceptions are (1) Functional and Dysfunctional Self-licensing items will be combined differently to create two means, one for each, (2) the mean of the Emotional Appetite Scale items will be taken for positive and negative emotions differently and (3) instead of the mean, the sum of scores will be used to create cognitive flexibility score of the participants.

The caloric value of the snacks reported will be assessed by multiplying the amount of the snack eaten with the caloric value of the snack. The caloric values will be obtained from different sources to be sure of the reliability of the snacks' caloric values. For the packaged snacks, the caloric information at the back of the packages will be used. For those snacks and drinks that are not packaged, the caloric information will be taken from https://www.diyetkolik.com/kac-kalori/, https://www.diyetasistan.com/besinler-kac-kalori.html, https://www.kackalori.com.tr/KaloriCetveli/ to be sure of the caloric values. 

After calculating each of the snacks and drinks' caloric value, they will be transformed into four different indexes. These four variables will be healthy snack mean, healthy drink mean, unhealthy snack mean and unhealthy drink mean. The mean of any of the above variable for a participant will be calculated by dividing the sum of caloric intake by 7. Beside from fruits, vegetables and yogurt, all the rest of the snacks will be coded as unhealthy snacks. In a similar vein, tea, sugar-free coffee, milk, mineral water will be coded as healthy drink and the rest (coke, alcoholic beverages etc.) will be coded as unhealthy drink.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For the hypotheses 1 and 2, hierarchical linear regression analysis will be used to analyze our proposed hypotheses. In both analyses, self-control, BMI will be added to the first step, and dysfunctional self-licensing (hypothesis 1) and functional self-licensing (hypothesis 2) to the second step.

For the remaining hypotheses (1a, 1b, 1c, 2a, 2b, 2c) moderation analysis will be conducted, according to the proposed predictions.

attributes.title: Socioemotional competencies, student engagement and performance at university – a cross-cultural project

q1.value: Emotional competence and prosocial behaviour as predictors of student engagement at the university: a cross-cultural multilevel analysis.

q2.value: Anabela Caetano Santos, Celeste Simões, Patricia Arriaga, Carmel Cefai, Celso David, Crispiniano Furtado, Eleni Andreou, Emanuel Frazão, Emily Shieh, Marcia Melo Bertolla, Nicola Schutte, Rita Psyllou, Surbhi Sehgal

q3.value:
Student engagement is understood as one of the most important predictors for academic success. It is a broad concept that depicts students’ commitment, motivation, interaction and involvement with the learning institution and learning activities with predictors both at individual and social-cultural levels. In educational research, student engagement has been conceptualized as a multidimensional construct (Appleton, Christenson, & Furlong, 2008) with three dimensions – emotional/affective, behavioural, and cognitive (Fredricks, Blumenfeld, & Paris, 2004; Furlong & Rebelez-Ernst, 2013; Furlong et al., 2003; Jimerson, Campos, & Greif, 2003). Studies using samples of college students have found positive associations between student engagement and academic achievement (Carini, Kuh, & Klein, 2006; Gunuc, 2014; Kuh, Cruce, Shoup, Kinzie, & Gonyea, 2008), school persistence (Kuh et al., 2008), college completion (Price & Tovar, 2014), physical and psychological well-being (Salmela-Aro & Read, 2017; Schaufeli, Martínez, Pinto, Salanova, & Barker, 2002). Even though research in this area is vast, not much attention has been given to this process in the university, in particular the role of emotion in student engagement in higher education (Kahu, 2013). 
Socioemotional competencies can be distinguished in two domains: intrapersonal and interpersonal. Intrapersonal are competencies used for a healthy functioning, and interpersonal are competencies used for adequate interactions with others (Domitrovich, Durlak, Staley, & Weissberg, 2017). Socioemotional competencies are important resources in maintaining mental health (Domitrovich et al., 2017), being predictors of well-being, academic performance (Brackett & Rivers, 2013) and college completion (Taylor, Oberle, Durlak, & Weissberg, 2017). Thus, the present study expands previous research by examining the role of emotional competence and prosocial behaviour as predictors of student engagement. 
Individual level variables, such as grade, gender and socioeconomic status, have shown to be predictors of student engagement among adolescent samples (Amir, Saleha, Mohd Jelas, Ahmad, & Hutkemri, 2014; Chiu, Pong, Mori, & Chow, 2012; Greene, Marti, & McClenney, 2008; Lam et al., 2016), but information is lacking in respect to college students. Student engagement is also largely influenced by sociocultural variables (Kahu, 2013), with positive contextual factors affecting the increase of engagement (Ungar & Liebenberg, 2013). Thus, we will analyse the role of the reviewed HDI2018 (Human Development Report, 2019), since the country’s socioeconomic development is associated with access to education, namely with entry in higher education and schooling years. The second country level predictor will be employment rate. The job market is considered to influence students’ engagement mainly in situations of economic crises (Tinto, 1975), with unemployment considered to be a relevant concern among college students (Reis & Matos, 2019). Decisions related with going to college and dropouts generally are related to their views about the job market and the likelihood of getting a job (Stuart, Rios-Aguilar, & Deil-Amen, 2014).

q4.value:
The following predictions are made:
Students with high emotional competences (H1) and prosocial behaviour (H2) will report higher engagement. 
Students in countries with higher country socioeconomic development (H3) and employment rate (H4) will report higher engagement. 
Country socioeconomic development (H5) and employment rate (H6) will moderate the impact of both emotional competences and prosocial behaviour on student engagement.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Cross-sectional study.
In this study, students are the first level and countries are the second level of analysis. Multilevel regression model analyses will be employed to examine the associations between emotional competences, prosocial behaviour and student engagement at the student level and how these associations may be affected by country socio-economic development and by employment rate at the country level. 
We expect to perform Multilevel regression model analyses using the lmer package in the software R (Bates, Maechler, Bolker, & Walker, 2014), although other statistical software might be used if needed.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value:
Overall, we are starting the data collection. Data was collected in one country (Malta) and is being collected in Portugal. The study will also be performed in at least other five countries which have not started the data collection.
No country has started data observation nor data analysis. The database will only be accessible after data collection is completed. Completion of questionnaires will be checked by exporting the automatic Qualtrics software variable “finished”. Thus, we will be able to verify how many complete questionnaires were already collected while not accessing the data.

question.value: Participants will be recruited via non-probability convenience and snowball sampling procedures through university communication services, social networks, during classes and through flyers distribution in public spaces close to university settings. The dissemination contains the study information and the link or the Qr code to facilitate the access to the online questionnaire while preserving the anonymity and the confidentiality.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants in each country. We will attempt to recruit up to 300, assuming not all participants will complete the questionnaire.

question.value:
This study is part of an extended project (https://osf.io/hqkgw/). Because not all measures will be used for this study, this document only presents the measured variables required for the present analysis. 
All measures in use are self-reported and will be mainly used in English and Portuguese versions, which were previously validated. For countries where English or Portuguese is not a first or second language, translation and transcultural adaptation will be performed using Beaton, Bombardier, Guillemin, and Ferraz (2000) guidelines for self-administered measures. 
Emotional Skills and Competence Questionnaire (ESCQ, Faria & Santos, 2009; Takšić, 2000) comprises a total of 45 items and has three subscales: i) Ability to perceive and understand emotion (15 items); ii) Ability to express and label emotion (14 items); and iii) Ability to manage and regulate emotion (16 items), all answered on a 3-point scale, ranging from 0 (Not true) to 6 (Certainly true).
Prosocial behaviour will be measured with the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ; Fleitlich, Loureiro, Fonseca, & Gaspar, 2004; Goodman, 2001). SDQ comprises a subscale of Prosocial Behaviour with five items, answered on a 3-point scale, ranging from 0 (Not true) to 5 (Certainly true).
Student Engagement will be assessed with the Student Engagement Scale (SES), previously developed in an international study with 12 countries (Lam et al., 2014). SES comprises three engagement subscales: i) affective (emotional) (9 items), ii) behavioural (12 items); and iii) cognitive (12 items). Both affective and behavioural subscales are answered on a 5-point scale, ranging from 1 (Strongly disagree) to 5 (Strongly agree), whereas the cognitive is answered on a 5-point scale, ranging from 1 (Always) to 5 (Never). 
Sociodemographic characteristics consist of age, gender, academic year, grades, nationality and generation university status, i.e. if student’s parents attended university or not (Gibson & Slate, 2010). Socioeconomic status is measured with the Family Affluence Scale (FAS; Currie et al., 2008), which comprises four items that reflects family resources (e.g. car ownership, own computer ownership, number of vacations per year, having an individual room). The FAS score is calculated for each person based on the responses to these four items on an ordinal three-point scale, composed for analysis, where: FAS 1 (score = 0 - 3) = indicates low turnout; FAS 2 (score = 4 - 6) = indicates mean turnout; FAS 3 (score = 7 - 9) = indicates high turnout (Currie et al., 2008). Participants under the social care services living in residential care homes will be included in the lower status.
Country variables includes socio-economic development and employment rate. The Human Development Index (HDI) will be used to capture the degree of socio-economic development of the countries involved. This index was developed by the United Nations as a comparative measure for development across countries.(Human Development Report, 2019). It combines four dimensions: i) life expectancy at birth, ii) expected years of schooling, iii) mean years of schooling and iv) gross national income per capita. The HDI provides a global measure of socio-economic development of countries worldwide. The employment rate per country as provided by Trading economics, an online platform that provides historical data, economic forecasts, news, and trading recommendations (https://tradingeconomics.com/).
Please see the document "Statistical models".

q21.value:
Data from a participant will be excluded if:
-	failed attention check items, 
-	have more than 20% of missing data, 
-	age under 18 or above 25
-	are not students at the moment the study was performed
For the model inference criteria, we will calculate maximum likelihood estimation using both full maximum likelihood and restricted maximum likelihood, using the latter to account for the relatively small sample at the second level of analysis (Bryk & Raudenbush, 1992).

q24.value: At the student level, the effects of gender, socioeconomic status, and academic year will also be examined.

q25.value:
Acknowledgments 
The Portuguese National Foundation for Science and Technology (FCT) funded this study through the grant SFRH/BD/126304/2016 awarded to the first author. The authors would also like to acknowledge João Daniel, PhD, for his support as a statistical consultant.

attributes.title: Dissociating movement curvature and response time as cognitive processes measures

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Dissociating movement curvature and response time as cognitive processes measures

sample.value: Assuming a small effect size of d_z=.3, we will collect at least 71 observation in order to achieve a power of at least 80%. Data will be collected over a fixed period (between March 18 and April 19, 2020). During this period as many observations as possible will be collected. If by the end of the data collection period the sample size goal has not been reached, we will continue data collection until 71 observations have been reached.

analyses.value: The study's main hypothesis will be analyzed by comparing the bivariate correlations of movement curvature  with the expected processing fluency and response competition. The correlations will be determined within-individual and then compared using a paired t-test. Analogously, we will compare and evaluate the bivariate correlations between (log-transformed) response time and the expected processing fluency and response competition.

outliers.value: Consistent with previous studies using the animal categorization task employed here, we will focus our analyses on correct responses. Furthermore, we will exclude from the analysis participants and items with a correct response rate lower than 60%. Finally, only participants whose mother tongue is German or who have learned German as a second language but prior to age 6 will be included in the analysis.

dependent.value: The two dependent variables central to this investigations are movement curvature and response time. Both variables will be measured within a computerized two-alternative, forced-choice task. Response time is measured as the duration between the trial initiation and the subsequent choice of the participant. Movement curvature is measured by continuously tracking the position of the computer mouse in-between trial initiation and choice, and evaluating the signed maximum (perpendicular) distance of the resulting trajectory to an idealized straight line between the start position and the eventually chosen option, which is known as the maximum absolute deviation (MAD).

conditions.value: There will be no between-subject or within-subject conditions. However, the study will be based on items that vary continuously with respect to the degree of processing fluency and response competition that they should elicit. Processing fluency and response competition are estimated as (log-transformed) word frequency and word relatedness (cosine similarity), respectively. Both are derived from natural language corpora.

hypothesis.value: In recent years, mouse- and hand-tracking have become popular tools to trace the cognitive processes involved in many cognitive domains. However, some of the fundamental questions concerning the validity this approach have not yet been addressed. Most importantly, we are still lacking clear evidence that mouse- and hand-tracking systematically deliver additional information over and beyond an established, less complex measure of the cognitive process, namely response times. In this investigation, we seek to provide this evidence. Specifically, our goal is to dissociate movement curvature and other measures of mouse- and hand-tracking from response times by studying their association to two distinct cognitive components, namely processing fluency and response competition. Consistent with the predominant view on mouse- and hand-tracking, our hypothesis is that movement curvature is correlated more strongly to response competition than to processing fluency, whereas the opposite should hold for response times.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: 400 HITS will be created via Amazon Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value: We will conduct a multiple regression model to see whether numerical ability and accuracy in growth rate estimation significantly predict peoples' approval of policy instruments. Control variables are personal affectedness, perception of Corona Virus severity, being a person who is especially at risk, education, income, gender, religious affiliation.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who fail to correctly answer the attention check.

dependent.value: The dependent variable will be the approval rating of 12 different policy instruments that aim to reduce the spreading of the new Corona Virus (ranging from 0 = not reasonable at all to 5 = extremely reasonable). The policy instrument vary in their level of infringement.

conditions.value: There are no conditions that participants will be assigned to.

hypothesis.value: We will investigate people's approval of (potential) policy instruments that aim to reduce the spreading of the new Corona Virus. We hypothesize that people with low numerical ability and low ability to accurately estimate growth rates are less likely to approve policies that impose a particularly strong infringement of personal liberties.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Approval to Corona Virus Policies.
registration_responses.sample: 400 HITS will be created via Amazon Mechanical Turk.
registration_responses.analyses: We will conduct a multiple regression model to see whether numerical ability and accuracy in growth rate estimation significantly predict peoples' approval of policy instruments. Control variables are personal affectedness, perception of Corona Virus severity, being a person who is especially at risk, education, income, gender, religious affiliation.
registration_responses.outliers: We will exclude participants who fail to correctly answer the attention check.
registration_responses.dependent: The dependent variable will be the approval rating of 12 different policy instruments that aim to reduce the spreading of the new Corona Virus (ranging from 0 = not reasonable at all to 5 = extremely reasonable). The policy instrument vary in their level of infringement.
registration_responses.conditions: There are no conditions that participants will be assigned to.

attributes.title: Vicarious Dissonance in a French Context: Reacting to the Inconsistency of Others
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), between-subject factor.
IV2: Measuring environmental behavioral intentions (Time 1 and Time 2), within-subject factor (repeated measure)

question2b.value:
The dependent variable will be the change in environmental behavioral intentions, measured in two steps: step 1 (i.e., pre-experimental measurement, before the vicarious dissonance procedure) and step 2 (i.e., post-experimental measurement, after the vicarious dissonance procedure). This scale, obtained from a pre-test, consists of five items: "I intend to buy products that pollute as little as possible", "I intend to choose products made from recycled materials", "I intend to buy organic products", "I intend to eat local products" and "I intend to buy seasonal products" (1 = never, 2 = very rarely, 3 = rarely, 4 = sometimes, 5 = often, 6 = very often, 7 = always).
These pre- and post-experimental intra-individual measures of behavioral intentions will allow us to measure and analyze the magnitude of change in behavioral intention, more specifically, the magnitude of reduction in dissonance (Martinie et al 2013).

question3b.value:
We will measure the proximity with the group as a covariate (measured in the pre-experimental questionnaire). Our measure of proximity with the group consists of 4 measures: group prototypicality, social identification with the group, similarity and interpersonal proximity to the group. 
1. The measure of prototypicality was based on the study by Hogg, Cooper-Shaw, & Holzworth (1993). Participants were asked to identify the characteristics of the group of youth (18 to 25 years of age) and to describe a prototype in no more five lines. They will then be asked to indicate how difficult it was for them to generate this description (1 = very easy, 7 = very difficult), how confident they were that this was an accurate description (1 = not very convinced, 7 = very convinced), and what percentage of the group they think generally agrees with their description. Finally, the prototypicality of the participants will be measured in 1 item: "How typical of the group of young people do you consider yourself to? "(1 = not at all representative, 7 = very representative), adapted in French from studies by Hogg, Cooper-Shaw, and Holzworth (1993). 
2. Social identification with the participant's group will be measured in 1 item, "I strongly identify with the youth group" (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (Reysen, Katzarska-Miller, Nesbit, & Pierce, 2013). 
3. The IOS scale (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992) will measure interpersonal closeness to the group, and 
4. similarity to the group will be measured in 4 items, "How do you feel similar to the person in general", "...in terms of personal dispositions", "...in terms of attitudes", and "...in terms of background," (1 = not at all similar, 7 = very similar), adapted in French from the studies of Stephan, Liberman, & Trope (2011).

question10b.value:
To participate in this study, students will register on a platform. They will be given a brief presentation of the study, and will be asked to complete a pre-anipulation questionnaire online in order to participate in the study.

Premanipulation questionnaire. This questionnaire will include several measures: 
- Environmental Behavioral Intent Scale (Dependent Variable, Time 1)
- Proximity to the group (covariate)
- Demographic information (sex, date of birth, parents' socio-professional category, initials)

1. For the presence of vicarious dissonance condition: 
Participants will be greeted by an experimenter who will tell them that this is a paired study. The experimenter will then stage a telephone conversation with another experimenter during which he or she will learn that the other participant has arrived. 
Once the participants are seated in the experiment room, the experimenter will tell them that this is a computer study. The experimenter explained that he was studying linguistic subcultures, to explore whether the mere fact of living together might cause unique speech patterns to develop (Norton et al., 2003). We stressed these potential differences between groups to make group concerns salient (Turner et al., 1987). The experimenter will specify that in his research, he is particularly interested in the language differences between the youth group (18-25 years old) and the senior group (65-75 years old), and that the paired participant who performs the experiment at the same time as him is also part of the youth group. It will be indicated that this person is of the same sex as him/her: if it is a girl student, we will say that the pair is a girl, if it is a boy, we will say that the pair is a young man (control of group membership). The experimenter will then explain to the participants that in order to study these linguistic subcultures, one of the participants will have to write an argumentative text in favor of environmental behavior, while the other will judge this argumentative text on a set of linguistic criteria. Our cover story was corroborated by having a tape recorder and micro- phone on the table in each of the two experimental rooms. Once the instructions have been given, the experimenter will leave the experimental room and the participant will perform the tasks on the computer.

After reading a brief article on linguistic subcultures, all participants will be led to believe that the computer randomly assigns the position of judge or writer of the argumentative text. For the credibility of the cover, while waiting for their pair to write the argumentative text, participants will fill in the same demographic information as in the premanipulation questionnaire (allowing us to link the pre- and post-manipulation questionnaires). Then, participants will be asked to read the argumentative text for environmental behavior written by their pair. To give the impression that the author is hypocritical about agreeing with pro-environmental behavior, the argumentative text will be followed by a question asking whether they always save energy. He will then be asked to recall the last time or times when he could have saved energy but did not. To this question, the author will answer: "Sometimes I waste water when I wash the dishes or take a shower", "I leave the heating on when I leave the house for several days", and "I leave my appliances on standby instead of turning them off". The participant will then respond to the dependent measures and manipulation check in the postmanipulation questionnaire. 

Postmanipulation questionnaire. 
- Environmental Behavioral Intent Scale (Dependent Variable, Time 2)
- Manipulation check (affiliation with the writer's group)

2. For the absence of vicarious dissonance condition:
Participants will complete only the postmanipulation questionnaire, with dependent measure (i.e., environmental behavioral intention un time 2), without following a vicarious dissonance procedure. 

We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two equally sized, predetermined blocks 
For randomization, we will use https://www.random.org/integers/

question4b.value: Participants will be undergraduate student from Aix Marseille University, recruited through advertisements. Participants will be between 18 and 25 years old and will participate in study for experimental credit. Recruitment will take place from February 17 to March 31 at the most, until sufficient participants are recruited for the study.

question5b.value: We will post participant sign-up slots by week on the preceding Friday night, with 85 spots posted per week. We will post new slots each week if, on that Friday night, we are below 100 participants.

question6b.value: Our target sample size is 82 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 100, to provide for participant exclusions. An a-priori power analysis using G*Power 3.1.5 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009) showed that 82 participants were necessary to detect a low effect size of .10 at the standard with an α-level of .05 and a power of .80

question7b.value: As soon as we get 82 reliable data.

question9b.value:
We will stop the experiment as soon as a participant asks for it. Moreover, we will provide participants with the opportunity to opt-out the study after completing the experiment.

A manipulation check will also be measured (see Procedure - postmanipulation questionnaire) to ensure that participants have been attentive to the procedure. Any participants who do not have a correct answer to this question will be excluded from the study.

question6c.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the Paired Samples T-Test and Repeated Measures ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons.

question7c.value:
As the questionnaires are filled out on computer, the participants are obliged to fill in the requested information in order to continue the experiment. 
Participants who have not completed the premanipulation questionnaire prior to the study will not be able to complete the experiment.

question1a.value:
H1. We expect that participants who observe the hypocritical behavior of an ingroup member will experience vicarious dissonance, which they will reduce by bolstering their support for the hypocrite’s normative advice.

Specifically, there will be a bolsterement of environmental behavioral intentions towards the environmental norm only when the participant is exposed to a hypocritical ingroup member.

question2a.value:
H2. We expect that participants who observe the hypocritical behavior of an ingroup member will experience vicarious dissonance, which they will reduce by  bolstering their support for the hypocrite’s normative advice, especially since they are strongly identified with the ingroup.

Specifically, we predict that more highly identified observer will be bolstering their environmental behavioral intentions towards the environmental norm after exposure to a hypocritical ingroup member.

question3a.value:
A pre-test was conducted to define a measure of environmental behavioral intentions, through two pre-tests. These are environmental behavioral intentions 1) for which students did not have too much intention at the outset (pre-test 1) (to avoid a ceiling effect), and 2) for which students had strong perceived behavioral control (pre-test 2). 

In addition, we will use some manipulation check. After the vicarious induced hypocrisy procedure (post-experimental questionnaire), the perception of the hypocritical discrepancy will be checked by two questions: "The writer believes in the importance of practicing environmental protective behaviors" and "The writer does not practice environmental protective behaviors regularly" (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) (Focella, Stone, Fernandez, Cooper, & Hogg, 2016). They will then be asked to indicate the affiliation of the writer, indicating whether they were part of the youth group or the senior group.

question1c.value:
Vicarious dissonance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants in the condition "presence of dissonance", and the number “0” for participants in the condition "absence of dissonance".

Measurement of environmental behavioral intention: Participants will indicate on a scale of 1 to 7 their environmental behavioral intention, in time 1 and time 2. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, two measures of their environmental behavioral intention, pre- and post-manipulation. 

Change in environmental behavioral intention. The change in environmental behavioral intention will result from the difference obtained between the measure of environmental behavioral intention at time 1 and the measure of environmental behavioral intention at time 2.

question2c.value: To measure the change in environmental behavioral intention as a function of the presence or absence of vicarious dissonance, we will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the measurement time (time 1 and time 2) as an intra-subject factor (repeated measures) and the vicarious dissonance (presence or absence) as an inter-subject factor.

question3c.value:
IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), inter-subject factor. 

IV2: Measurement of environmental behavioral intention (time 1 and time 2), intra-subject factor. 

DV: change in environmental behavioral intention.

question1c.value:
Vicarious dissonance: It will be attributed the number “1” for participants in the condition "presence of dissonance", and the number “0” for participants in the condition "absence of dissonance".

Measurement of environmental behavioral intention: Participants will indicate on a scale of 1 to 7 their environmental behavioral intention, in time 1 and time 2. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, two measures of their environmental behavioral intention, pre- and post-manipulation. 

Proximity with the group: We will take the mean of the four questions (self-prototypicality, social identification at the group, similarity and interpersonal closeness with the group) to create a single measure of “proximity with the group”. We will therefore obtain, for each participant, a score of "proximity with the group" on a scale of 1 to 7. 

Change in environmental behavioral intention: The change in environmental behavioral intention will result from the difference obtained between the measure of environmental behavioral intention at time 1 and the measure of environmental behavioral intention at time 2.

question2c.value: To measure the change in environmental behavioral intention as a function of the presence or absence of vicarious dissonance and as a function of proximity with the group of participant, we will perform a repeated measures ANOVA with the measurement time (time 1 and time 2) as an intra-subject factor (repeated measures), the vicarious dissonance (presence or absence) as an inter-subject factor, and proximity with the group as covariate.

question3c.value:
IV1: Vicarious dissonance (presence versus absence), inter-subject factor. 

IV2: Measurement of environmental behavioral intention (time 1 and time 2), intra-subject factor. 

Covariate: proximity with the group.

DV: change in environmental behavioral intention.

question4c.value: Vicarious dissonance predicts that only observers highly identified with the group who observe the hypocritical behavior of another ingroup member will experience dissonance vicariously (Cooper & Hogg, 2007).

attributes.title: Rumination and Suicidal Behaviour: The role of hallucination-proneness in a non-clinical sample.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: STUDY DESCRIPTION: Rumination and Suicidal Behaviour: The role of Hallucination-Proneness in a non-clinical sample.

sample.value: In correspondence with the values outlined in Table 1 of Schonbrodt and Perugini (2013) in order to achieve a reasonable level of precision, we aim to recruit a sample of approximately 212 participants, since we expect correlation coefficients of r = .30.

analyses.value:
Zero-order correlation coefficients will be examined between levels of rumination (RRQ scores), visual hallucination-proneness (MUSEQ-V scores), auditory hallucination-proneness (MUSEQ-A scores) and suicidal behaviour (SBQ-R scores). We expect positive associations between all of these variables.
This will be followed by a multiple regression analysis to examine to what extent rumination, visual hallucination-proneness and auditory hallucination-proneness independently predict suicidal behaviours. The analysis will control for participants age, gender, ethnicity, socioeconomic status and levels of negative affect. Subsequently scores of the rumination measure (RRQ) will be entered into the regression model. In the final step of the model, scores on the MUSEQ-V and the MUSEQ-A will be entered. If the results of the regression analyses are consistent with the predicted mediating effect, we will use INDIRECT, an SPSS macro to formally test for mediation. This examines the indirect effects of the predictor variable (RRQ scores) on the outcome variables (SBQ-R scores) through mediating variables (MUSEQ-V and MUSEQ-A scores) using a bootstrapping sampling procedure.

dependent.value: Participant’s score on the Suicidal Behaviour Questionnaire (Revised; SBQ-R) will be the primary dependent variable.

hypothesis.value: Do visual hallucination-proneness and auditory hallucination-proneness mediate the association between rumination and suicidal behaviour?
